title: Banking & Finance:  Larry Fink Says  Company Is Looking  Into Crypto Sector  ----  By Paul Vigna
text:
BlackRock Inc. is an investor in a $400 million fundraising round for Circle Internet Financial, the crypto-focused company that manages the stablecoin USD Coin.

Other investors in the round included Fidelity Investment Inc., Marshall Wace and Fin Capital.

Circle has raised $1.1 billion overall, according to Crunchbase. The company is planning to go public through a special-purpose acquisition company later this year.

The USD Coin has become the second-largest stablecoin, with about $51 billion in circulation. Stablecoins are digital assets designed to trade on par with national currencies such as the U.S. dollar and backed by matching reserves.

During a conference call Wednesday morning, Larry Fink, BlackRock's chief executive, said BlackRock has been working with Circle over the past year as a manager of some of Circle's cash reserves. He said he expects BlackRock eventually to be the primary manager of those reserves. "We look forward to expanding our relationship," he said.

BlackRock has over $9 trillion in assets under management.

Mr. Fink said the firm is also studying the crypto sector broadly, including assets, stablecoins, permissioned blockchains and "tokenization," where it perceives a benefit to its customers. "We are increasingly seeing interest from our clients," he said.

Mr. Fink's name came up last week during the Miami 2022 bitcoin conference.

Peter Thiel, the PayPal Holdings Inc. co-founder who has become a vocal bitcoin booster, delivered a speech in which he advocated developing an "enemies list" of people opposed to bitcoin.

He singled out Berkshire Hathaway Inc. Chief Executive Warren Buffett, JPMorgan Chase & Co. CEO Jamie Dimon and Mr. Fink.

In a letter to investors last month, Mr. Fink said a well-designed digital-money system could cut cross-border costs, improve global-transactions settlements and help cut down money laundering.
